meetup-Bucharest-Data-Science-Meetup-235.description:
This session will be an introductory talk on how to use Neo4J ( https://neo4j.com/ ) in its capacity as a graph analytics engine. The target audience is SQL developers.

We'll start with an overview of Neo4J and its query language Cypher before moving on to a few worked examples where we'll build and query the same data set using first relational databases and then Neo4J.

We'll also cover graph modeling, query optimization and show an example of procedures which were introduced in the 3.0 version of Neo4J.

What is Neo4J?

Here's a good summary by Emil Eifrem, creator of Neo4J:
Most applications today handle data that is deeply associative, i.e. structured as graphs (networks). The most obvious example of this is social networking sites, but even tagging systems, content management systems and wikis deal with inherently hierarchical or graph-shaped data.
This turns out to be a problem because it’s difficult to deal with recursive data structures in traditional relational databases. In essence, each traversal along a link in a graph is a join, and joins are known to be very expensive. Furthermore, with user-driven content, it is difficult to pre-conceive the exact schema of the data that will be handled. Unfortunately, the relational model requires upfront schemas and makes it difficult to fit this more dynamic and ad-hoc data.
A graph database uses nodes, relationships between nodes and key-value properties instead of tables to represent information. This model is typically substantially faster for associative data sets and uses a schema-less, bottoms-up model that is ideal for capturing ad-hoc and rapidly changing data.
meetup-Bucharest-Data-Science-Meetup-235.title: Presentation - Beginners - Introduction to Neo4J

meetup-Bucharest-Java-User-Group-2376598.description:
Presentation - Intermediate - Brainstorming your way from a Monolith to a Clean Architecture

Speaker: Victor Rentea

Did you ever wanted to (re)write your enterprise application from scratch? I’m sure you did ! And I’m pretty sure the rewritten codebase would be two times smaller than it is now. But, given the time and budget for a rewrite, what would you do to keep it from becoming “legacy” again in 2 years?


Ok, Wake Up! Your boss won’t approve a rewrite! But still, what should you aim for with your asiduous refactorings and clean-ups?


Let me share with you what I believe to be the ideal mindset about an enterprise application: Pragmatic, Clean Evolutionary Architecture.


Pragmatic = Keep It Short & Simple

Clean = The Onion Architecture (Dependency Inversion Principle)

Evolutionary = Continuously redesign

Architecture = that will ensure Developer Comfort & Safety.

Tests, tests, tests = Responsible Development


It’s all basically a summary of the design principles that we distilled over the past 2 years developing 7 enterprise applications for our client (one of the largest of IBM Romania).

Agenda:

1) Introduction: KISS, DDD vs Transaction Script

2) Modeling Data

The Fit Entity that obeys you

Value Objects

Data Transfer Objects that isolate your Entities

3) Extracting Logic

Mappers that encapsulate conversion

Facades that implement logic

Extracting Domain Services for KISS or DRY

Logic Extraction Patterns

4) The Clean Architecture

Dependency Inversion Principle -- the best of OOP (cf. Uncle Bob)

Consuming Repositories

Calling External Services

5) Testing

Principles - Design Feedback

Testability

A new style of TDD: Extract and Split


My goal with this talk is basically to open the eyes of enterprise application developers to think critical of the (often) imposed enterprise architecture they follow, and to empower them to think out-of-the-box. Hopefully, they will then be able to tackle unexpected functional complexity with an appropriate minimalistic design that would maintain a low design complexity (=less code =happier developers). It's a story that I've gone through with teams on numerous projects, although I didn't had the chance to talk about it in any public event until now.


To keep things simple, the discussion will conceptually start from a simplistic one-class system and grow the architecture with additional patterns, justifying at all times the added complexity with fundamental principles of good design + a lot of discussions. Basically, I would love to hear you continuously arguing with me why I’ve added the complexity as I present it to you. This way, adding constructs as we go, we’ll end up very close to the architectures that we actually use today for our apps at my work.


Even though the talk is more on a conceptual level, you’ll see some code examples that support my decisions.


Target audience: Enterprise application developers (JavaEE, Spring, even non-Java) with at least 3 years of hands-on backend experience.


The talk will only address the backend architecture (from the controller to the database).


References: Clean Code (Robert C. Martin), Rethinking Java EE Patterns (Adam Bien), TDD by example (Kent Beck), Extreme Programming Explained (Kent Beck)
meetup-Bucharest-Java-User-Group-2376598.title: Presentation - Brainstorming your way from a Monolith to a Clean Architecture

meetup-Bucharest-Mobile-Development-Meet.description:
Hey all,  


We're glad to announce a new Mobile Developers Meetup, on February 27th 2016!  

Join us for two presentations at the Microsoft HQ, the sponsor of the event. 
Drinks and snacks included.

---

1. Kotlin features for Android - Valentin Iorgu, Lead Mobile Developer at mReady

The Android development experience has improved considerably in the last couple of years thanks to some great libraries and tooling improvements but we're still stuck with an outdated version of Java while other platforms get shiny new toys like Swift. 


You might have heard of Kotlin (also during our last meetup), but how exactly does it help?
In this presentation we'll go over several Kotlin features that help reduce boilerplate, can increase the stability of your codebase and enhance the overall development experience.

We'll explore things like inline functions, reified generics, receiver lambdas, delegated properties, sneak peak  at coroutines and more.

---

2. Azure for Android – Radu Matei, Technical Evangelist at Microsoft

In this hands-on presentation, we will explore the capabilities of building your Android application by creating a cloud-based back-end, with integrated authentication and authorization, offline data sync, push notifications and autoscale.


See you there,  
The Mobile Academy team

---

Agenda
18:30 - 19:00 Registration & networking  
19:00 - 19:40 Valentin Iorgu, mReady 
19:40 - 20:20 Radu Matei, Microsoft 
20:20 - 21:00 Networking

meetup-Cluj-Napoca-Python-and-Big-Data-2.description:
How do you build a transaction monitoring platform which will effectively combat money laundering and terrorist financing? Machine Learning will be at the heart of your solution, but which architecture best fits your needs? In this two part discussion we will answer these questions and offer our advice and anecdotes on navigating the wonderful world of Machine Learning and its practical applications.

Part 1 - Transaction Monitoring and Money Laundering

Every day, millions of transactions between people or organisations take place, amongst which there might, just might, be some that are suspicious. Our job is to identify these transactions and why they do not fit a normal pattern. Hence, why we built our transaction monitoring platform.

We will be talking about the reasons why this platform needed to be both generic and flexible and  how we achieved this. We will go on to discuss: 

• Why different clients have different needs depending on the information they choose to  store on their transactions.

• Why traditional SQL tables are not entirely suited to this application and why NoSQL is a natural alternative, as we still need all the traditional layers of validation and normalisation of external input.

• The challenge of building an engine that is optimised to process large numbers of  transactions, whilst at the same time being flexible enough to support all the different styles of analysis that are required to detect money laundering and terrorist financing.

• And in terms of performance how far you can take ORM and when it is acceptable to take  matters into your own hands. Finally, we will discuss splitting business logic between Python code and database queries.

Part 2 - Machine Learning Supermarket Paralysis

Over the last three years deep learning has exploded in popularity and the quality of the results has greatly improved. Big tech companies have increased their research budgets in order to benefit from this revolution. As a direct consequence several of these (Microsoft, Google, Facebook, Amazon) have released open frameworks for training and developing deep architectures such as: TensorFlow, CNTK, FBLearner, MxNET and Caffe.

Beside these, other popular existing frameworks and wrappers coming mainly from academia, have gathered a great deal of support (Theano, Torch7, Scikit-learn, Keras).

With such a broad choice, it's no surprise that choosing the "right" Machine Learning (ML)  framework can lead to a paradox of choice (especially for beginner ML students). This talk will give an overview of what ML frameworks are and what they do. We will discuss in more detail TensorFlow, Scikit-learn, Theano and Keras, highlighting the pros and cons for each of these frameworks. Finally, we will demonstrate them by applying them to a simple linear regression task.

Persic Alexandru Cristian (Backend Lead) studied Computer Science at "Stefan cel Mare" University, followed by a Master’s degree in software engineering (apparently 5 years of  study was not good enough). At university he started working at an outsource company using Microsoft technologies and enjoyed each step from helping with JavaScript to implementing custom workflows in SharePoint. After 5 years he saw the light and moved to Python/Django, building a mobile advertising platform from the ground up. In 4 years he managed to gain plenty of experience in managing the implementation, deployment and maintenance of a large scale web application. In 2016 Cristi made a daring move and joined ComplyAdvantage in the quest of finding once more the excitement of building a new and successful product, all the while fighting crime like any other regular superhero.

Ariel Pontes (Python Engineer) studied Computer Engineering at the Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro. After learning Python/Django in his first internship in a fin tech startup he fell in love with MVC frameworks, and re-wrote his final year project in Ruby on Rails. In 2014 he moved to Cluj and started working as a full-stack Django developer in a big outsourcing company. Ariel joined ComplyAdvantage in 2016 where he works on the transaction monitoring and screening platforms. Outside of work you can find him participating in activism for local NGOs and preaching about secular ethics.

Oana Ratiu (Python Engineer) graduated from Babes-Bolyai University, Cluj-Napoca, studying computer science, and is currently completing her Master's Degree in Databases. She has worked as a programmer for three years, mostly with Python. Excited to fight terrorism through her work, Oana joined ComplyAdvantage in early 2016, working on a transaction monitoring platform and, more recently, on a screening platform.

Cristian Lungu (Senior Python/ML Engineer) wrote (anti)viruses for fun and profit for 5 years until he realised how much money flows through the stock market. He then spent his next 5 years coding derivatives, futures and options. Somehow, he was kidnapped and dropped on this startup ship called ComplyAdvantage where fighting terrorists and money laundering with machine learning is the only way to get a meal. As a result of this event, he challenged himself to actually finish his lifelong hobby, a PhD in machine learning, this century. When he doesn't code he's probably teaching bubble sort at the UTCN or  conducting practical studies of gradient descent on some mountains.

Schedule:

19:00 - 19:15 - Let's take a break, enjoy some refreshments and network some more! 

19:15 - 20:00 - presentation continues

 To ask questions;

meetup-Cluj-WEB-Developers-237632838.description:
Fighting macro-corruption with microservices - theory, back-end, front-end, Docker and Kubernetes 


No longer does one app “rule them all”

From a user experience perspective, architectural styles have evolved to what we now might call "pay by the drink". Where we don’t just offer a single monolithic platform, we offer a multidimensional approach where users can pick and choose the workflows and micro apps of their choice.

A similar trend is also happening in software development, where microservices are now the mainstream approach for scalable systems architecture. Many software engineers are making the transition from monolithic architectures to microservice architectures. This approach has until most recently been limited to back-end services. As development is much more complicated when using microservices as building blocks for a frontend solutions, especially with the latest JS frameworks that promote a monolithic approach to front-end architecture.

We will give an overview of the theory of microservices – what they are and why you would use them. We will then delve into the dark arts of back-end development, explaining how you can construct a winning product with microservices whilst avoiding its pitfalls. We will also discuss methods of rolling your own Frontend app in a world of backend microservices and tackling the challenges of monolithic frontend apps when working with microservices as backend.
  The presentation will cover:

• Background on what microservices are and why you would use them

• A walk through of a backend application development and architecture using microservices to compare and contrast  traditional architectural methodologies

• A discuss on the ways of rolling your own frontend app in a world of backend microservices and ways of tackling challenges of having a monolithic frontend app working with microservices as backend

• Finally, no discussion of microservices would be complete without touching on the integration of Docker and Kubernetes from a developer’s perspective
 

Speakers:

Oliver Butterfield (Platform Lead) is ComplyAdvantage’s primary driving towards adopting a microservice architecture. Oliver previously worked in the server hosting industry and as one of the first team members became the de facto DevOps Engineer in the early days of ComplyAdvantage. Fast forward three years and he's now overseeing development of our client-facing services, including the refactoring of the core application from a monolith to microservices. Oliver is currently excited by distributed computing and performance technologies, such as Kubernetes, AWS, NewRelic and Go.

Persic Alexandru Cristian (Backend Lead) studied computer science at "Stefan cel Mare" University, followed by a masters degree in software engineering (apparently 5 years of study was not good enough). At University he started working at an outsource company using Microsoft technologies and enjoyed each step from helping with JavaScript to implementing custom workflows in SharePoint. After 5 years he saw the light and moved to Python/Django, building a mobile advertising platform from the ground up. In 4 years he managed to gain plenty of experience in managing the implementation, deployment, and maintenance of a large scale web application. In 2016 Cristi made a daring move and joined ComplyAdvantage in the quest of finding once more the excitement of building a new and successful product, all the while fighting crime like any other regular superhero.
  Kun Andrei (FrontEnd Lead) graduated from Technical University of Cluj-Napoca, studying Electronics, Telecommunications and Information Technology. Since then he's been working as a Web Developer on both backend and frontend, though finally focussing on the latter. He followed his passion for UI and the latest frontend technologies. After he gained experience with various corporations and outsourcing companies he was lured by the opportunities of a young and ambitious startup team where he could take ownership of his work and put his own mark on products. Joining ComplyAdvantage was the right step in this direction, he now takes care of the company's front-end apps.
  Andrew Smith (DevOps Lead) studied Mathematics at Warwick University (UK). Graduating in 2012 with no idea what he wanted to do as a career, he fell into a Release Engineering Role at a London FinTech company. Three years later, in January 2016, he joined ComplyAdvantage as their first DevOps Engineer (a far more morally fulfilling role). He has implemented technology, infrastructure, and procedures to effectively and reliably go "From Idea to Production" (to quote GitLab) and to keep everything highly available once it's there. Outside of work, you'll most likely find him at the nearest venue playing loud music, performing culinary experimentation or creating fine works of art in MS Paint.

meetup-Cluj-py-237665198.description:
Location: ClujHUB


Schedule:

6PM - Entry

There will be pizza, courtesy of ComplyAdvantage.


6:30 - Transaction Monitoring and Money Laundering (Cristi Persic, Oana Ratiu, Ariel Pontes)

Every day, millions of transactions between people or organizations take place, amongst which there might, just might, be some that are suspicious. Our job is to identify these transactions and why they do not fit a normal pattern. Hence, why we built our transaction monitoring platform. We will be talking about the reasons why this platform needed to be both generic and flexible and how we achieved this. We will go on to discuss:

• Why different clients have different needs depending on the information they choose to store on their transactions. Why traditional SQL tables are not entirely suited to this application and why NoSQL is a natural alternative, as we still need all the traditional layers of validation and normalization of external input.

• The challenge of building an engine that is optimised to process large numbers of transactions, whilst at the same time being flexible enough to support all the different styles of analysis that are required to detect money laundering and terrorist financing.

• And in terms of performance how far you can take ORM and when it is acceptable to take matters into your own hands. Finally, we will discuss splitting business logic between python code and database queries.

7:15 - Break

7:30 - Machine Learning Supermarket Paralysis (Cristi Lungu)

Over the last three years deep learning has exploded in popularity and the quality of the results has greatly improved. Big tech companies have increased their research budgets in order to benefit from this revolution. As a direct consequence several of these (Microsoft, Google, Facebook, Amazon) have released open frameworks for training and developing deep architectures such as: TensorFlow, CNTK, FBLearner, MxNET and Caffe. Beside these, other popular existing frameworks and wrappers coming mainly from academia, have gathered a great deal of support (Theano, Torch7, Scikit-learn, Keras). With such a broad choice, it's no surprise that choosing the "right" Machine Learning (ML) framework can lead to a paradox of choice (especially for beginner ML students). This talk will give an overview of what ML frameworks are and what they do. We will discuss in more detail TensorFlow, Scikit-learn, Theano and Keras, highlighting the pros and cons for each of these frameworks. Finally, we will demonstrate them by applying them to a simple linear regression task.

8:15 - Closing

___________________________

Persic Alexandru Cristian (Backend Lead) studied computer science at "Stefan cel Mare" University, followed by a masters degree in software engineering (apparently 5 years of study was not good enough). At university he started working at an outsource company using Microsoft technologies and enjoyed each step from helping with JavaScript to implementing custom workflows in SharePoint. After 5 years he saw the light and moved to Python/Django, building a mobile advertising platform from the ground up. In 4 years he managed to gain plenty of experience in managing the implementation, deployment and maintenance of a large scale web application. In 2016 Cristi made a daring move and joined ComplyAdvantage in the quest of finding once more the excitement of building a new and successful product, all the while fighting crime like any other regular superhero.
   
Ariel Pontes (Python Engineer) studied Computer Engineering at the Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro. After learning Python/Django in his first internship in a fintech startup he fell in love with MVC frameworks, and re-wrote his final year project in Ruby on Rails. In 2014 he moved to Cluj and started working as a full-stack Django developer in a big outsourcing company. Ariel joined ComplyAdvantage in 2016 where he works on the transaction monitoring and screening platforms. Outside of work you can find him participating in activism for local NGOs and preaching about secular ethics.
   
Oana Ratiu (Python Engineer) graduated from Babes-Bolyai University, Cluj-Napoca, studying computer science, and is currently completing her Master's Degree in Databases. She has worked as a programmer for three years, mostly with Python. Excited to fight terrorism through her work, Oana joined ComplyAdvantage in early 2016, working on a transaction monitoring platform and, more recently, on a screening platform.

Cristian Lungu (Senior Python/ML Engineer) wrote (anti)viruses for fun and profit for 5 years until he realised how much money flows through the stock market. He then spent his next 5 years coding derivatives, futures and options. Somehow, he was kidnapped and dropped on this startup ship called ComplyAdvantage where fighting terrorists and money laundering with machine learning is the only way to get a meal. As a result of this event, he challenged himself to actually finish his lifelong hobby, a PhD in machine learning, this century. When he doesn't code he's probably teaching bubble sort at the UTCN or conducting practical studies of gradient descent on some mountains.

Advanced Java 8 w. Richard Warburton

-The masterclass for Java developers

Richard Warburton - Independent Software Developer, Book Author and Technical Trainer, is speaker on March 23 at Java Day Iasi. He will support a hands-on workshop about Advanced Java 8.

Topics:

· Data Parallelism

· Testing and Debugging Lambdas

· Default and static methods on interfaces

· Enhanced Design with Lambdas

· Date & Time in Java 8

· The Optional data type

· CompletableFuture

About Richard:

Richard is an empirical technologist and solver of deep-dive technical problems and works independently as a Software Engineer and Trainer. 

He has written the book on Java 8 Lambdas for O’Reilly and he is a leader in the London Java Community. Richard is also a well known conference speaker, having talked at Devoxx, Javazone, JavaOne, JAX London, JEEConf, Codemotion Rome, and many more others. He obtained a PhD in Computer Science from The University of Warwick.

You can find more details here:

www.iasi.javaday.ro

Register at [masked]. 

Java Day is an unique event, designed for technical team leads, architects, engineering directors, and project managers who influence innovation in their teams, and takes place every year in Cluj-Napoca, Timisoara, Iasi and Bucharest.

meetup-Product-Camp-Bucharest-Meetup-237.description:
Hi Productcampers,

This month Andrei Romanescu, mentor for go-getters, will talk about "How to Accelerate Your Startup and Turn it Into a Business"

Throughout his 20-years career, Andrei developed a strong passion for People, Operational Excellence and Customer Delight. He likes to see opportunities when everyone else spots challenges, build on strengths, and strategize businesses.

Here is a short summary of his talk:

"Having a full time job and developing your own business in parallel? Possible. 

What does a premium desserts business has in common with IT? Quite a lot. 

Join us and find out how a family turned a hobby that had nothing to do with their day2day jobs into a business with an annual growth rate of 70%-80%. 

Listen to their story about:

(a) how they developed and marketed the products;

(b) how they differentiated the brand and increased sales on a very competitive market driven by price; 

(c) the challenges they had to overcome and mistakes they made as entrepreneurs so you avoid the traps. 

The sweet business we will be talking about: www.cupcakephilosophy.ro; 

www.facebook.com/cupcakephilosophy"

As always in the second part we have Open Space and you are invited to bring your topics about Product Development, Startup Businesses, or anything else related to our topic.

Agenda:

18:45 - 19:00  Welcome Product Campers

19:00 - 19:10  Intro

19:10 - 20:10  "Accelerate your startup. Turn it in2 a business" by Andrei Romanescu

20:10 - 20:20  BREAK

20:20 - 21:15    OPEN SPACE

See you there!

Adrian & Vlad

Dear Softbinator friends,


On Wednesday, February 22, we are super excited to invite you to Talks #93! Can you imagine that we’re only 7 editions away from our 100th meetup? By the way, how do you think we should celebrate this? Drop us a line if you have any cool ideas on this matter.


Long story-short: let’s get back to business; bellow you can check out the details regarding the discussion topics and the speakers that will rock the stage at Talks #93! Don’t forget that this is a community driven series of events, so if you’d like to recommend a speaker to us, feel free to reach out anytime!


Event agenda:


19:00 - 19:15 - Welcome!


19:15 - 19:45 - Adrian Stratulat → Hacking at work - Technical solutions for "impossible" problems

While working as programmers, we sometimes encounter "impossible" situations, where the usual approaches fail and we are left with more "unorthodox" solutions.

This presentation is about 4 different scenarios which happened at work, when I had to use reverse-engineering and penetration-testing just to get the job done.


19:45 - 19:50 - Break


19:50 - 20:20 - Constantin Nilă → Security in Web Application


20:20 – Q&A - Networking! :D


Price ticket: IT&C knowledge, tech enthusiasm, beer fan and a big amount of positive energy!


If you like this event, you know the drill: Join it! Like it! Share it! Spam it! Hack it! Harder, faster, stronger, better.

meetup-Tabara-de-Testare-Cluj-237661190.description:
Hello!

This meetup is a do-over, updated session from the testing track at Codecamp Cluj.

The content owner will be Levente Florisca. During this presentation, he aims to cover the following:

What is software testing? It is simply understanding the functionality and architecture of a piece of software and test it until fear of not finding any bugs turns to boredom? But what about coding? Is that required for a tester or it is a knowledge exclusively for developers? Does coding help in the software testing? Is automation a fantasy, in a euphoric world? The difference between software delivering and software developing / testing is a topic which can be discussed until the edge of infinity. The pros and cons of each side will be discussed from a QA point of view.

Levi started to learn, after few years he was asked to tutor, teach and train others in the magical land of automation and testing. He's been holding workshops and training at companies for more than 2 years now, the rest of his info can be tracked on social media.

***About TdT

1. Meetup starts at 18:30.

Please show up at 18:15 to ensure a smooth and proper start of the event.

2. Each meetup has the following workflow:

- by the organizers/facilitators: introduction to Tabara de Testare

- by the speaker: speaker background & then the presentation / workshop itself

- each participant is invited to donate 15 lei to cover the expenses for the location


3. TdT online presence:

- Blog: http://tabaradetestare.ro/

- Slideshare: http://www.slideshare.net/tabaradetestare

- Twitter: @tabaradetestare

- Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Tabara.de.Testare?fref=ts

! Please mention if you do not wish to be photographed or have your picture posted online !

Thank you,

TdT Team

meetup-The-Bucharest-Agile-Software-Meet.description:
This time, we are going to use test driven development (TDD) to implement the Berlin Clock. 

The specifications of this rather odd clock are:

The time is calculated by adding the lit rectangular lamps. 
The top lamp is a pump which is blinking on/off every two seconds. 
In the upper line of red lamps every lamp represents 5 hours. 
In the lower line of red lamps every lamp represents 1 hour. So if in the first line 2 lamps are lit and in the second line 3 lamps its 5+5+3=13h or 1 p.m. 
In the third line with tall lamps every lamp represents 5 minutes. 
There are 11 lamps, the 3rd, 6th, and 9th are red indicating the first quarter, half, and the last quarter of the hour. 
In the last line with yellow lamps every lamp represents 1 minute.

If you're wondering, this clock really exists in Berlin. Learn more about it on Wikipedia.

A Coding Dojo is a team practice format that accelerates knowledge transfer and sharing skills between team members. With an experienced facilitator, it is also a way of learning by applying various techniques. Objectives

The following skills are typical candidates for improvement during a dojo:

• Refactoring
• Simple design
• Clean code
• Improving pair programming technique
• How to safely modify code you don't understand (usually legacy code)
• Learning a new programming language
• Unit testing
• Test driven development

In addition, coding dojo can be used by a team as a collective and structured way of solving difficult or risky problems related to production, like fixing a bug or redesigning parts of the application.

How it works?

The basic format of a coding dojo:

• All developers and the facilitator gather in a room.
• The facilitator introduces the purpose and the format of the coding dojo.
• One laptop with a functional development environment is connected to a projector.
• Two developers pair program on the laptop. The others are in the room, watching the code changes.
• Every 7 minutes, one developer leaves the laptop and the next one from the room takes his place.
• After a specified period of time (usually around two hours), the dojo ends with a retrospective.
meetup-The-Bucharest-Agile-Software-Meet.organizer: The Bucharest Agile Software Meetup Group
meetup-The-Bucharest-Agile-Software-Meet.title: Coding Dojo - Implementing the Berlin Clock using TDD

meetup-Timisoara-Automotive-Technology-M.description:
This first Timisoara Automotive Technologies Meetup edition in 2017 will include a talk by Mirela Lazar, Business Development Manager at Timișoara subsidiary of the Aachen-headquartered FEV GmbH and her colleagues, Marius Mircea and Catalin Niculescu. 


Mirela's presentation, titled "Functional Safety in Model Based Development" will analyse how, nowadays, the car evolved to being more than a means of transportation, while the design, development and industry processes has also evolved to superior levels, allowing the customer to enjoy the comfort of the trip and entitling it to demand from the vehicle to make the travel more economical, safer and in the same time to provide an overall better (or a none- :) ) driving experience. 

More about Mirela Lazar

With roughly 9 years of experience in Automotive Software Development, Verification and Validation in various domains, 5 of which spent abroad, working hands in hands with teams from various European OEM's, Mirela is bringing her expertise and mindset to the table while establishing a new FEV office in Romania. 

More about FEV

FEV is an internationally recognized leader in the design and development of both conventional and alternative transportation energy systems. FEV is a major supplier of advanced testing and instrumentation products and services and successfuly delivers design, analysis, prototyping, simulation, development, integration and production support services.


We may add an entry to the schedule, so stay tuned!

Also, you can now follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/AutomotiveTM20

See you!
meetup-Timisoara-Automotive-Technology-M.title: Functional Safety in Model Based Development
meetup-Timisoara-Automotive-Technology-M.venue: Timisoara Startup Hub : 10th, C. Brediceanu St., E Building, Timisoara, Timisoara

meetup-Timisoara-UX-UI-Group-237708641.description:
Hi everyone,

Meetup #14 comes Wednesday, February 22nd, with a few surprises. 

I would like to warmly welcome Bogdan Negrescu and Adonis Răduca as my colleagues and co-organizers of the UX/UI Meetup in Timișoara. May this be the beginning of an interesting and long journey! :)

We prepared two topics for the evening:

Conceptual Design

Simplicity and familiarity, are two important factors of any user-centered design solution. True simplicity and familiarity, are first and foremost achieved, by a carefully considered conceptual model.

This session is about designing great conceptual models, with a fresh and intriguing perspective on the subject.

Presented by Adonis Raul Răduca,
Experienced UX Designer interested in Artificial Intelligence


Needfinding Strategies


Good products respond to customer demand. Great products respond to customer needs.

One effective starting point for designing new technology is to clearly identify an existing problem or need.

Needfinding tools, methods, tips and tricks, all during our conversation this evening.


Presented by Claudiu Dungă
GUI Designer at Canon inc., interested in Innovation Management


Meetup schedule: 


18:45-19:00 
Welcome & informal introductions

19:00-19:55 
Conceptual Design


19:55-20:00
Short break to switch presenters

20:00-20:55 
Needfinding

21:00-21:15
Casual discussion

Make sure you don't miss the opportunity to get a better understanding of two key, but neglected, aspects of UX Design.


See you Wednesday, February 22nd! :) 

Claudiu, Adonis and Bogdan.
meetup-Timisoara-UX-UI-Group-237708641.title: UX/UI Timisoara Meetup #14

Dear UX/UI Designers,

Our friends at UXProject Bucharest invite you to the first meetup held in Cluj (at ClujHUB).

If you want to participate make sure to RSVP on their event page.

Agenda

19:00 - 19:15 - Welcome & Intro

19:15 - 19:45 - Presentation (to be announced)

19:45 - 20:00 - Short Break

20:00 - 20:45 - How to Run an UX Workshop with Clients & Stakeholders / Andrei Mihai

5 simple Design Thinking tools and methods that you can use in your day to day activity that will help you get a fast understanding of your customer needs and your client business model.

20:45 - 21:45 - Networking 


Session will be held in Romanian.

meetup-angularjs-cluj-237753304.description:
Freelancing is seen from the outside as waking up late, working from coffee shops and making more money than the average employee. Some of these are true, but freelancers also deal with risk, late payments, difficult clients, uncomfortable timezones, distributed teams and more. It takes discipline, very good communication skills, some sales & marketing techniques and top notch technical know-how to make it as a successful freelancer.

To kick off the discussion we invited Tudor Fis to tell us about his experience as a freelancer. He has been working since 2009 for various clients in Europe and the US. If you are thinking about freelancing or you are already an experience freelancer we’d love to meet you. It will be an open discussion. Looking forward to your questions!
meetup-angularjs-cluj-237753304.title: Freelancing: how to start and how to succeed

meetup-angularjs-cluj-zhpzmmywdbcc.description:
Starting today we are planning on holding a recurring meetup in which we will discuss, document, build and more importantly contribute to open source projects.

We have used open source projects in our every day job, but rarely had the chance to contribute back and understand the environment better.

This meetup will help you improve your developer skills, working in a team, understanding how open source works and how to architect, develop and maintain an open source project.

The event will last for 2 hours in which we will do the following:

1. Discuss code you already worked on that you are thinking of making open source

2. Discuss ideas of open source projects you would like to contribute to

3. Organise your project: code, architecture, comments, issues, PRs, community message.

4. Contribute by writing code to one or multiple github repositories.

At the end of each event we will take a look at what PRs have been added/merged, see how we can improve our code and share new ideas with the community.

Requirements:

• laptop


• 2 hours of your time


• fun learning attitude


This event is as free as open source.
meetup-angularjs-cluj-zhpzmmywdbcc.title: Workshop: Contributing to Open Source

meetup-aws-ro-237241801.description:
Hi Everyone,

We have our presenter for Feb 23rd.

Marius Mitrofan has once been tasked with developing a fully functional MyBB forum that was of course expected to be highly-scalable, highly-available and as secure as possible. So he chose to use AWS CloudFormation and then he wrote a tutorial on how he did - https://netbears.ro/devops/launch-mybb-cloudformation-stack-aws/.

For our next meeting Marius will present it as a practical use case for AWS CloudFormation and VPC.

See you next time!

Ciprian
meetup-aws-ro-237241801.title: Launch a MyBB stack using AWS CloudFormation

meetup-clujytech-237671313.title: Kickoff Event
meetup-clujytech-237671313.venue: Bulgakov Cafe: Inocentiu Micu Klein, 17, near the old city wall, Cluj-Napoca

meetup-fullstack-cluj-237753304.description:
Freelancing is seen from the outside as waking up late, working from coffee shops and making more money than the average employee. Some of these are true, but freelancers also deal with risk, late payments, difficult clients, uncomfortable timezones, distributed teams and more. It takes discipline, very good communication skills, some sales & marketing techniques and top notch technical know-how to make it as a successful freelancer.

To kick off the discussion we invited Tudor Fis to tell us about his experience as a freelancer. He has been working since 2009 for various clients in Europe and the US. If you are thinking about freelancing or you are already an experience freelancer we’d love to meet you. It will be an open discussion. Looking forward to your questions!
meetup-fullstack-cluj-237753304.title: Freelancing: how to start and how to succeed

Starting today we are planning on holding a recurring meetup in which we will discuss, document, build and more importantly contribute to open source projects.

We have used open source projects in our every day job, but rarely had the chance to contribute back and understand the environment better.

This meetup will help you improve your developer skills, working in a team, understanding how open source works and how to architect, develop and maintain an open source project.

The event will last for 2 hours in which we will do the following:

1. Discuss code you already worked on that you are thinking of making open source

2. Discuss ideas of open source projects you would like to contribute to

3. Organise your project: code, architecture, comments, issues, PRs, community message.

4. Contribute by writing code to one or multiple github repositories.

At the end of each event we will take a look at what PRs have been added/merged, see how we can improve our code and share new ideas with the community.

Requirements:

• laptop


• 2 hours of your time


• fun learning attitude


This event is as free as open source.

meetup-the-javascript-timisoara-group-23.description:
How do you "type" JavaScript?

In the context of having various JavaScript flavors & languages that compile to JS, which offer static typing, the aim of this meetup is to answer a few questions:


• will static types make us write better code?
• will static types reduce the number of bugs?
• are dynamic languages suited for "small" projects only?
• can I mix static & dynamic types?
• should I switch to a statically typed JavaScript flavor?

To help us answer these questions, we have invited 2 special guests:

• Radu Marinescu
• Radu Fericean


Moderator: Andrei Pfeiffer

This meetup will take place in a panel-like format, no presentations. The audience is welcome to contribute to the discussion.

<Have a subject you want to talk about? Contact us. We're always eager to hear from you!>
meetup-the-javascript-timisoara-group-23.title: tim.js meetup 36: How do you "type" JavaScript?

Agenda

17:30 Networking și răsfoirea revistei

17:45 Deschiderea evenimentului 

18:00 Prezentări articole

- Transformarea digitală cu ajutorul Sistemelor Embedded - Irina Muresan (NTT Data)

- Are you happy at work? What makes the difference? - Daniela Păun (Endava)


- Cele șapte păcate capitale ale produsului tău: Imprudența Avariției - Natalia Zincenco (Betfair)

- Serverless computing folosind Azure Functions - Denis Salanța (VE Interactive)


- Rapid prototyping cu RubyOnRails - Sagar Ranglani (Crossover)


19:00 Pauză & networking

19:30 Andy Tryba - CEO of Crossover and RideAustin

19:50 Startups a la Cluj 

ProcessPlayer.ro - Daniel Homorodean (Arxia)

20:10 Expert talks panel - IT-ul clujean în 2017


Unde suntem și ce se poate face pe piața locală. Vom vorbi despre eveniment european important care va avea loc în Cluj anul acesta, strategii și proiecte inițiate de primărie și companiile locale.

Invitați:

- dl. primar Emil Boc

- Daniel Metz - fondator EBS, companie care a devenit NTT Data

- Bianca Muntean - director executiv Aries Transilvania

- Andrei Kelemen - director executiv Cluj IT Cluster


- Bogdan Herea - CEO @ PITECH+PLUS


* Participarea este gratuită

** Evenimentul este găzduit de NTT Data

***  Evenimentul a fost publicat și pe pagina TSM de Facebook 

**** Participanții vor primi ultimul număr tipărit al revistei Today Software Magazine
